Title: Fictious unit-conversion problems
Description: Those problems involve unit conversion to/from fictious units.
Author: O. Moussa

Title: Vector Addition and Subtraction with Three Vectors.
Description: The problem bank asks students to calculate the vector operation of three vectors, given their magnitude and direction. One of those vectors has an angle defined with respect to the y-axis. There are three distractors each problem: Direct addition of magnitude with two randomly chosen angles, and ignoring the angle with the y-axis (swapped components of one of the vectors.)
Author: Leo Murch

Title: Angular Momentum of a Particle Multiple Answers
Description: This problem bank contains multiple answer problems that ask students to select the observer that measure the same or opposite angular momentum of a particle traveling in a straight line as a reference observer.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Conservation of Angular Momentum by Changing Moment of Inertia
Description: To be added
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Math Expression for Simple Harmonic Motion
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Motion w Constant Acceleration along 1D
Description: Problem set for 1 segment of UAM along 1D.
Author: O. Moussa

Title: 1D Kinematics with Non-Constant Acceleration
Description: A simple one-dimensional kinematics problem that involves integrating a non-constant acceleration function to find the objects position and velocities at fixed reference positions and times.
Author: Michael Jay Perez

Title: Projectile motion involving half the trajectory
Description: This problem bank consists of projectile motion calculation problems involving a projectile that either started from a height with horizontal velocity, or launched to a target at the peak of the trajectory.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Comparison of flight time in parabolic trajectory
Description: Asks students to compare the flight time of three projectile motion trajectories.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Identification of Newton's third law pair
Description: Contains multiple answer problems for which students are required to identify Newton's 3rd law pairs of forces, and distinguish from the forces that are not N3 pairs.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Newton's 2nd Law of Motion Elevator Concept Questions
Description: A set of simple conceptual questions testing Newton's 2nd Law of motion and direction of a Force given directions of velocity and acceleration/decceleration.
Author: Michael Jay Perez

Title: Newton's third law force pairs
Description: This is an example problem bank for assessment problems. Use this template to create new problem banks by replacing the content with your own questions and details.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: One Force at an Angle with Kinetic Friction
Description: Those problems involve an object subjected to an external force applied at an angle, and is moving with kinetic friction. The external force affects the normal force between the object and the surface.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Static block on ramp with compressed spring and friction
Description: A set of isomorphic problems involving a block in static equilibrium on an inclined plane. The block is acted upon by a compressed spring, an external pulling force (tension), gravity, and static friction, with all non-gravitational forces acting up the ramp.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Static Friction MC Problem Bank
Description: An applied force at an angle is acting on an object. The object remains at rest. The goal is to find the static friction. A common mistake is to use static friction coefficient times normal force to get static friction.
Author: Tong Wan

Title: Identification of free body diagram forces
Description: Multiple-answer question, Identification of free body diagram forces
Author: Owen Raymond

Title: Determining acceleration from forces
Description: An applied force at an angle is acting on an object on a rough surface. Calculate the acceleration.
Author: Tong Wan

Title: Determining acceleration_MC version
Description: An applied force at an angle is acting on an object on a rough surface. Calculate the acceleration.
Author: Tong Wan

Title: Accelerating elevator categorization problem
Description: This is a bank of conceptual physics problems designed for a university-level course to test students' understanding of **Newton's Second Law** in one-dimensional vertical motion. The problems are presented in a **categorization format**, where students must match a specific description of an object's motion to the correct physical relationship between the external applied force (like tension or normal force) and the object's weight. Each question is grounded in a relatable, real-world scenario (e.g., an elevator, a crate on a forklift, a bucket on a crane) and covers all six fundamental states of vertical motion: * Speeding up while moving upward or downward * Slowing down while moving upward or downward * Moving at a constant velocity upward or downward
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Calculation of Work Done by Varying Force
Description: Calculation of Work done by a changing force over a distance.
Author: Owen Raymond

Title: Mechanical Energy Conservation Conditions
Description: This bank contains categorization/drag and drop problems that ask students to categorize situations based on whether mechanical energy is conserved for the system.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Mechanical Energy with External Work
Description: This problem bank contains problems that belong to four variations: 1. an object being dropped from a height into a viscous liquid, airbag, or thick soft material, or deploys a parashoot, rocket or booster, where the object experiences some resistance or upward force, which can be approximated as constant. 2. an object of mass m being launched up a ramp with  initial velocity v. The object experience some resistance going up the ramp for a length of d and height of h. 3. an object being launched horizontally from a spring, or a mechanism that can be modeled as an ideal spring such as a bow or a sling shot. The object experiences constant non-conservative resistance such water resistance or a rough track, and reaches some velocity after traveling for a little distance after being launched. 4. an object traveling with some initial velocity on a rough track or in some dense fluid such as oil or water, or experience significant air resistance for a distance, before being slowed down by a spring, or a spring like object that can be modeled as a spring such as a rubber band or elastic net. The object experiences constant non-conservative resistance during the process, and compresses/extends the spring or rubber band for a distance before coming to a stop.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Change in linear momentum and impulse.
Description: This is an example problem bank for assessment problems. The problems have been updated to remove intermediate concepts like impulse and momentum as givens, requiring students to use the fundamental equations directly.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Collision and Explosion in 2D
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: What is conserved for multi-stage process categorization problem
Description: The description will be generated after all the problems are being created.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Moment of Inertia of Composite Objects Multiple Choice
Description: We can ask GPT to generate the description of the problem bank.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Rotational Kinematics -- finding Angular Displacement from three kinematic variables.
Description: This problem bank contains problems that requires calculating the angular displacement given 3 other kinematic variables.

Title: Torque Balance On a Rod
Description: Torque balance on a uniform thin massiv rod, with one force at an angle, and one hanging block. The location of the force the block and the pivot changes between problems.
Author: Zhongzhou Chen

Title: Rotational Dynamics with Two Torques.
Description: This problem bank contains problems that
Author: Zhongzhou Chen
